data.author: 2reincarnated
data.content: If we go by the past and appreciate the SP was once a lot higher and the company is confirmed as headed back in that direction, no reason why we will not get 100% rises. However, getting back to the previous ''dizzy heights'' will be near impossible, thanks to all that dilution!
data.thread_title: RE: Buys coming in but showing as sell

data.author: Inatthedeepend
data.content: Im new to this platform hence the post count. What attracted me to Surface Transforms was the quality of their product and the production improvements that have bern made. Only Brembo make this product other than ST and when the two products were tested by General motors for a new contract, the ST item was better! So they have the best product in the world potentially...

data.author: Al180
data.content: Welcome to LSE Inatthedeepend. I'm sure ST has a superior product to Brembo, they have better heat dispersion allowing them to run hotter and perform more consistently from cold than Brembo.  Particularly important to the OEMs  is they can get the required performance using a smaller disc. Although both companies produce ceramic brakes, Brembo use small fragments of carbon that are eventually turned into Silicon Carbide and ST start with a woven carbon matrix, Kevin Johnson compared the difference between the two  to  Chipboard and Plywood. There are other companies producing ceramic brakes for the racing market but they are a long way from entering the global safety critical supply chain,  ST and Brembo look like being the only option open to OEMs for some time to come.
data.thread_title: RE: Best product IN THE WORLD!

data.author: Al180
data.content: I’ve been looking into some numbers for the ZR1 relating to the current OEM10 contract. Initial production after a delay began in late April. By the end of July, only 180 units had been produced. Since then “Bloggers” that track production say it’s been growing quickly estimating 200 units per month run rate at the start of October. A search indicates ZR1 Bloggers use many different pieces of available information and are usually accurate. As ST supply front and rear brakes on the ZR1 this equates to 800 discs per month from this contract alone with five other smaller contracts also now in series production. No doubt GM would of stockpiled as many discs as they could knowing Surface transforms manufacturing problems when GMs own production was delayed and severely affected by supply chain issues so I wouldn’t expect revenue for ST to mirror the ZR1 run rate, however the number of cars being produced per month currently is more than the first seven months of the year in total. Hopefully this bodes well for H2 production rates and revenue.

data.author: 2reincarnated
data.content: Hope this does not go sub 2p before it goes +3p. Charts look good, but what are charts in effect?

data.author: Netzeroready
data.content: Drifted down a bit which was to be expected but the business is moving a great pace now with the turnaround fully in place. Expect a bounce back towards 3 p shortly as buyers move back in.

data.author: Marischal
data.content: It is not a woven matrix... weaving is 2D, not 3D. B
data.thread_title: RE: Best product IN THE WORLD!

data.author: Marischal
data.content: Brembo do not use "small fragments of carbon"...
data.thread_title: RE: Best product IN THE WORLD!

data.author: Marischal
data.content: Errata ...2D is a matrix...3D is a tensar. .my mistake apologies. ST's brakes have 3D fibre lays..fact

data.author: Fevertreeman
data.content: Inevitable that in the absence of news this drifts back - remember that we've had massive dilution here, and Kevin Johnson has serially f***** up so the real jury ( i.e. investors who have spent time understanding the product, the processes, the market , the customer base, and the barriers to entry)  remain highly sceptical of management's ability not to f*** this up again.  Johnson's history around forecasting, operational enhancements and scaling is dreadful. Given that furnace capacity is critical to the disc manufacturing process and therefore revenue, cashflow, & output, until we know for sure that Johnson hasnt yet again screwed it up, we're not likely to see any sustained recovery here. Although they've already telegraphed Q3 yield will be impacted by the installation, investors will be unlikely to pull the trigger until (10 we can see Q4 yields are steady and consistent c80pc (2) new CFO doing his thing and we're not about to have another liquidity issue.....we 're by no means out of the woods.....Cleminson has been superb in bringing us baxck from near death.....we're out of intensive care but still in the high dependency ward...my hope is that we can gradually move back to general ward, and then be discharged during 2026.

data.author: Al180
data.content: As long as the new CVI furnace becomes fully operational this year ST will be generating decent amounts of cash in 2026.  H2 2025 all going well will have been EBITDA  neutral  with £1m of cash at 2025 YE. This looks like the point where money could have got tight and the OEMs may have possibly made up a small shortfall but going forward capacity will double with the second CVI furnace. Demand is not an issue; the OEMs have wanted more discs than ST have been able to produce for a long time and  more of the £390m contracted pipeline kicks in this year. Unless yield or cash is well off the mark in the update progress with the new furnace is the most crucial thing,  apart from doubling capacity the second unit removes the last potential single point of failure in the production line

data.author: LatentValue
data.content: The lower productivity in H2 meant that rather than repay £3m of customer prepayments/advances in H2 as previously planned, they actually grew by over £0.4m.  Whilst this gap is disappointing it's now even clearer to me that GM/other OEMs should keep funding this project in the short/medium term until critical mass is achieved.  The working assumption between the company and funding OEMs must be that until this inflection point is reached, when a placing at a much higher market cap is more achievable and the prepayments can be settled from the raise, an early placing is not an option. Interesting also that at £27m sales they are suggesting breakeven EBITDA in FY26.  According to my financial model, £27m sales would result in positive EBITDA of £3m-£4m based on 77% yield.  It would therefore appear that they therefore are factoring in a big negative yield impact from the commissioning of the new furnace.  As per earlier comment: the OEMs would prepay this loss during H1. I would also hope IC has demanded great caution in the FY26 guidance, given the CEOs propensity to disappoint shareholders with over-optimistic guidance, today being a further example!

data.content: Im new to this platform hence the post count. What attracted me to Surface Transforms was the quality of their product and the production improvements that have bern made. Only Brembo make this product other than ST and when the two products were tested by General motors for a new contract, the ST item was better! So they have the best product in the world potentially...

data.author: Al180
data.content: Welcome to LSE Inatthedeepend. I'm sure ST has a superior product to Brembo, they have better heat dispersion allowing them to run hotter and perform more consistently from cold than Brembo.  Particularly important to the OEMs  is they can get the required performance using a smaller disc. Although both companies produce ceramic brakes, Brembo use small fragments of carbon that are eventually turned into Silicon Carbide and ST start with a woven carbon matrix, Kevin Johnson compared the difference between the two  to  Chipboard and Plywood. There are other companies producing ceramic brakes for the racing market but they are a long way from entering the global safety critical supply chain,  ST and Brembo look like being the only option open to OEMs for some time to come.
data.thread_title: RE: Best product IN THE WORLD!

data.author: Al180
data.content: I’ve been looking into some numbers for the ZR1 relating to the current OEM10 contract. Initial production after a delay began in late April. By the end of July, only 180 units had been produced. Since then “Bloggers” that track production say it’s been growing quickly estimating 200 units per month run rate at the start of October. A search indicates ZR1 Bloggers use many different pieces of available information and are usually accurate. As ST supply front and rear brakes on the ZR1 this equates to 800 discs per month from this contract alone with five other smaller contracts also now in series production. No doubt GM would of stockpiled as many discs as they could knowing Surface transforms manufacturing problems when GMs own production was delayed and severely affected by supply chain issues so I wouldn’t expect revenue for ST to mirror the ZR1 run rate, however the number of cars being produced per month currently is more than the first seven months of the year in total. Hopefully this bodes well for H2 production rates and revenue.

data.author: Fevertreeman
data.content: Inevitable that in the absence of news this drifts back - remember that we've had massive dilution here, and Kevin Johnson has serially f***** up so the real jury ( i.e. investors who have spent time understanding the product, the processes, the market , the customer base, and the barriers to entry)  remain highly sceptical of management's ability not to f*** this up again.  Johnson's history around forecasting, operational enhancements and scaling is dreadful. Given that furnace capacity is critical to the disc manufacturing process and therefore revenue, cashflow, & output, until we know for sure that Johnson hasnt yet again screwed it up, we're not likely to see any sustained recovery here. Although they've already telegraphed Q3 yield will be impacted by the installation, investors will be unlikely to pull the trigger until (10 we can see Q4 yields are steady and consistent c80pc (2) new CFO doing his thing and we're not about to have another liquidity issue.....we 're by no means out of the woods.....Cleminson has been superb in bringing us baxck from near death.....we're out of intensive care but still in the high dependency ward...my hope is that we can gradually move back to general ward, and then be discharged during 2026.
data.thread_title: RE: Best product IN THE WORLD!

data.author: Fevertreeman
data.content: 2012: full year revenues of c£2.4m (lower than forecast) 2022: full-year revenues of £5.1m (lower than revised forecasts)  .. 2023 : full year revenues of £7.3m below original/revised forecasts  (Jan 23..."the Company is not changing its guidance for 2023 and will be profitable" ; Apr 23 "Our overall profitability during FY 2023 is expected to be below market expectations." ); Nov '23 " As a result, the Company is reducing its sales guidance for the year to December 2023 to £8.6m" 2024: full-year revenues of £8.2m (lower than revised forecast)....  Jan '24 "The Company is maintaining its revenue guidance for 2024 at £23m" ; April '24 "projected FY 2024 range of £17.5m to £22m" ; Sept '24 " revenues ....now expected to be circa £11m .....significantly lower than current market expectations of £17.5m".
data.thread_title: For new investors or should that be punters....a little potted pain...

data.author: Fevertreeman
data.content: We're finally in a position where the management team actually looks like it knows what its doing. And cricually we have a chairman who will hold Johnson to account and a New NED who really does know his stuff. Meantime the  CFO who replaced Maddock  carries the scars from Saietta, so is a good hire. Maddock turned out, unfortunately , to be completely out of her depth, & was seriously at fault for the forecasting/liquidity mess . The replacement for Easton looks like he actually understands the business - Easton didn't prove a great hire either. Lets hope that the Board really hammered Johnson about £20m forecast......I'm hoping that Cleminson demanded that there was room on the upside because if we fail AGAIN to hit the forecast, we're back to Square oNe, as the endless excuses about capacity issues wont wash

data.author: Al180
data.content: As long as the new CVI furnace becomes fully operational this year ST will be generating decent amounts of cash in 2026.  H2 2025 all going well will have been EBITDA  neutral  with £1m of cash at 2025 YE. This looks like the point where money could have got tight and the OEMs may have possibly made up a small shortfall but going forward capacity will double with the second CVI furnace. Demand is not an issue; the OEMs have wanted more discs than ST have been able to produce for a long time and  more of the £390m contracted pipeline kicks in this year. Unless yield or cash is well off the mark in the update progress with the new furnace is the most crucial thing,  apart from doubling capacity the second unit removes the last potential single point of failure in the production line

data.author: LatentValue
data.content: The lower productivity in H2 meant that rather than repay £3m of customer prepayments/advances in H2 as previously planned, they actually grew by over £0.4m.  Whilst this gap is disappointing it's now even clearer to me that GM/other OEMs should keep funding this project in the short/medium term until critical mass is achieved.  The working assumption between the company and funding OEMs must be that until this inflection point is reached, when a placing at a much higher market cap is more achievable and the prepayments can be settled from the raise, an early placing is not an option. Interesting also that at £27m sales they are suggesting breakeven EBITDA in FY26.  According to my financial model, £27m sales would result in positive EBITDA of £3m-£4m based on 77% yield.  It would therefore appear that they therefore are factoring in a big negative yield impact from the commissioning of the new furnace.  As per earlier comment: the OEMs would prepay this loss during H1. I would also hope IC has demanded great caution in the FY26 guidance, given the CEOs propensity to disappoint shareholders with over-optimistic guidance, today being a further example!

Just not sure why they didn't pull the trigger when the sp was a bit higher.

data.author: Al180
data.content: As long as the new CVI furnace becomes fully operational this year ST will be generating decent amounts of cash in 2026.  H2 2025 all going well will have been EBITDA  neutral  with £1m of cash at 2025 YE. This looks like the point where money could have got tight and the OEMs may have possibly made up a small shortfall but going forward capacity will double with the second CVI furnace. Demand is not an issue; the OEMs have wanted more discs than ST have been able to produce for a long time and  more of the £390m contracted pipeline kicks in this year. Unless yield or cash is well off the mark in the update progress with the new furnace is the most crucial thing,  apart from doubling capacity the second unit removes the last potential single point of failure in the production line

data.author: jaari888
data.content: 0 0 UK, US to sign multibillion-dollar tech deal during Trump's visit (Reuters) -The United Kingdom and the U.S. are preparing to sign a landmark technology agreement in the coming days as part of President Donald Trump’s visit to the UK, the British Embassy in Washington said on Saturday. This agreement aims to bolster collaboration between the two nations' trillion-dollar tech sectors, enhancing opportunities for businesses and consumers on both sides of the Atlantic. While the final details were still being negotiated, the embassy said the partnership will focus on key technologies, including artificial intelligence, semiconductors, telecommunications, and quantum computing. “Cutting-edge technology such as AI and quantum computing will transform our lives,” UK Technology Secretary Liz Kendall, who was appointed to her role on September 5, said in a statement. Trump is set to fly to the UK on Tuesday for a second state visit, which is expected to last three days. He is due to be accompanied by a delegation of U.S. executives including Nvidia Corp CEO Jensen Huang and OpenAI's Sam Altman. BlackRock plans to invest $700 million in British data centers as part of a string of deals to be announced during Trump's state visit next week, Sky News reported on Saturday. Since the start of the year, both countries have published AI Action Plans. U.S. firms such as Anthropic and OpenAI are increasingly establishing international offices in London, while UK-based companies like DeepMind continue to invest in trans-Atlantic collaborations. https://finance.yahoo.com/news/uk-us-sign-multibillion-dollar-230734260.html

data.content: Currently P/E  ratio is 1.5 with estimated £20m sales this year and current £30m mCap. So where are the buyers, what will it take to drive the SP to a level that reflects it's value?

data.author: 30silver
data.content: Never have I seen more nonsensical valuations in my life.  P/E ratios are on earnings, you're using revenue.  Once the business is profitable and cash generate (remember the customers have been paying in advance to bankroll the Company) then we'll see a solid valuation, at the moment this looks like it's being driven by sentiment, and hope.  I've been in for a year, seen my investment lose 80% of it's value, then come right back up to the point where I sold 70% of my holding to repay the full initial investment and leave 30% effectively in there for free.  I'll cash out the lot once we break 3p and then 4p and walk away happy - perhaps it'll go to 10p, if you think this thing is going near £2Bn you're out of your mind, Brembo are only worth c.€3Bn FFS.

data.author: LatentValue
data.content: The lower productivity in H2 meant that rather than repay £3m of customer prepayments/advances in H2 as previously planned, they actually grew by over £0.4m.  Whilst this gap is disappointing it's now even clearer to me that GM/other OEMs should keep funding this project in the short/medium term until critical mass is achieved.  The working assumption between the company and funding OEMs must be that until this inflection point is reached, when a placing at a much higher market cap is more achievable and the prepayments can be settled from the raise, an early placing is not an option. Interesting also that at £27m sales they are suggesting breakeven EBITDA in FY26.  According to my financial model, £27m sales would result in positive EBITDA of £3m-£4m based on 77% yield.  It would therefore appear that they therefore are factoring in a big negative yield impact from the commissioning of the new furnace.  As per earlier comment: the OEMs would prepay this loss during H1. I would also hope IC has demanded great caution in the FY26 guidance, given the CEOs propensity to disappoint shareholders with over-optimistic guidance, today being a further example!

data.author: Fevertreeman
data.content: 2012: full year revenues of c£2.4m (lower than forecast) 2022: full-year revenues of £5.1m (lower than revised forecasts)  .. 2023 : full year revenues of £7.3m below original/revised forecasts  (Jan 23..."the Company is not changing its guidance for 2023 and will be profitable" ; Apr 23 "Our overall profitability during FY 2023 is expected to be below market expectations." ); Nov '23 " As a result, the Company is reducing its sales guidance for the year to December 2023 to £8.6m" 2024: full-year revenues of £8.2m (lower than revised forecast)....  Jan '24 "The Company is maintaining its revenue guidance for 2024 at £23m" ; April '24 "projected FY 2024 range of £17.5m to £22m" ; Sept '24 " revenues ....now expected to be circa £11m .....significantly lower than current market expectations of £17.5m".

data.author: Fevertreeman
data.content: Inevitable that in the absence of news this drifts back - remember that we've had massive dilution here, and Kevin Johnson has serially f***** up so the real jury ( i.e. investors who have spent time understanding the product, the processes, the market , the customer base, and the barriers to entry)  remain highly sceptical of management's ability not to f*** this up again.  Johnson's history around forecasting, operational enhancements and scaling is dreadful. Given that furnace capacity is critical to the disc manufacturing process and therefore revenue, cashflow, & output, until we know for sure that Johnson hasnt yet again screwed it up, we're not likely to see any sustained recovery here. Although they've already telegraphed Q3 yield will be impacted by the installation, investors will be unlikely to pull the trigger until (10 we can see Q4 yields are steady and consistent c80pc (2) new CFO doing his thing and we're not about to have another liquidity issue.....we 're by no means out of the woods.....Cleminson has been superb in bringing us baxck from near death.....we're out of intensive care but still in the high dependency ward...my hope is that we can gradually move back to general ward, and then be discharged during 2026.

data.author: Al180
data.content: I’ve been looking into some numbers for the ZR1 relating to the current OEM10 contract. Initial production after a delay began in late April. By the end of July, only 180 units had been produced. Since then “Bloggers” that track production say it’s been growing quickly estimating 200 units per month run rate at the start of October. A search indicates ZR1 Bloggers use many different pieces of available information and are usually accurate. As ST supply front and rear brakes on the ZR1 this equates to 800 discs per month from this contract alone with five other smaller contracts also now in series production. No doubt GM would of stockpiled as many discs as they could knowing Surface transforms manufacturing problems when GMs own production was delayed and severely affected by supply chain issues so I wouldn’t expect revenue for ST to mirror the ZR1 run rate, however the number of cars being produced per month currently is more than the first seven months of the year in total. Hopefully this bodes well for H2 production rates and revenue.

data.author: Al180
data.content: Welcome to LSE Inatthedeepend. I'm sure ST has a superior product to Brembo, they have better heat dispersion allowing them to run hotter and perform more consistently from cold than Brembo.  Particularly important to the OEMs  is they can get the required performance using a smaller disc. Although both companies produce ceramic brakes, Brembo use small fragments of carbon that are eventually turned into Silicon Carbide and ST start with a woven carbon matrix, Kevin Johnson compared the difference between the two  to  Chipboard and Plywood. There are other companies producing ceramic brakes for the racing market but they are a long way from entering the global safety critical supply chain,  ST and Brembo look like being the only option open to OEMs for some time to come.

data.author: LatentValue
data.content: The lower productivity in H2 meant that rather than repay £3m of customer prepayments/advances in H2 as previously planned, they actually grew by over £0.4m.  Whilst this gap is disappointing it's now even clearer to me that GM/other OEMs should keep funding this project in the short/medium term until critical mass is achieved.  The working assumption between the company and funding OEMs must be that until this inflection point is reached, when a placing at a much higher market cap is more achievable and the prepayments can be settled from the raise, an early placing is not an option. Interesting also that at £27m sales they are suggesting breakeven EBITDA in FY26.  According to my financial model, £27m sales would result in positive EBITDA of £3m-£4m based on 77% yield.  It would therefore appear that they therefore are factoring in a big negative yield impact from the commissioning of the new furnace.  As per earlier comment: the OEMs would prepay this loss during H1. I would also hope IC has demanded great caution in the FY26 guidance, given the CEOs propensity to disappoint shareholders with over-optimistic guidance, today being a further example!

data.author: Al180
data.content: As long as the new CVI furnace becomes fully operational this year ST will be generating decent amounts of cash in 2026.  H2 2025 all going well will have been EBITDA  neutral  with £1m of cash at 2025 YE. This looks like the point where money could have got tight and the OEMs may have possibly made up a small shortfall but going forward capacity will double with the second CVI furnace. Demand is not an issue; the OEMs have wanted more discs than ST have been able to produce for a long time and  more of the £390m contracted pipeline kicks in this year. Unless yield or cash is well off the mark in the update progress with the new furnace is the most crucial thing,  apart from doubling capacity the second unit removes the last potential single point of failure in the production line

data.author: LatentValue
data.content: The lower productivity in H2 meant that rather than repay £3m of customer prepayments/advances in H2 as previously planned, they actually grew by over £0.4m.  Whilst this gap is disappointing it's now even clearer to me that GM/other OEMs should keep funding this project in the short/medium term until critical mass is achieved.  The working assumption between the company and funding OEMs must be that until this inflection point is reached, when a placing at a much higher market cap is more achievable and the prepayments can be settled from the raise, an early placing is not an option. Interesting also that at £27m sales they are suggesting breakeven EBITDA in FY26.  According to my financial model, £27m sales would result in positive EBITDA of £3m-£4m based on 77% yield.  It would therefore appear that they therefore are factoring in a big negative yield impact from the commissioning of the new furnace.  As per earlier comment: the OEMs would prepay this loss during H1. I would also hope IC has demanded great caution in the FY26 guidance, given the CEOs propensity to disappoint shareholders with over-optimistic guidance, today being a further example!

data.author: Al180
data.content: As long as the new CVI furnace becomes fully operational this year ST will be generating decent amounts of cash in 2026.  H2 2025 all going well will have been EBITDA  neutral  with £1m of cash at 2025 YE. This looks like the point where money could have got tight and the OEMs may have possibly made up a small shortfall but going forward capacity will double with the second CVI furnace. Demand is not an issue; the OEMs have wanted more discs than ST have been able to produce for a long time and  more of the £390m contracted pipeline kicks in this year. Unless yield or cash is well off the mark in the update progress with the new furnace is the most crucial thing,  apart from doubling capacity the second unit removes the last potential single point of failure in the production line

data.author: Al180
data.content: I’ve been looking into some numbers for the ZR1 relating to the current OEM10 contract. Initial production after a delay began in late April. By the end of July, only 180 units had been produced. Since then “Bloggers” that track production say it’s been growing quickly estimating 200 units per month run rate at the start of October. A search indicates ZR1 Bloggers use many different pieces of available information and are usually accurate. As ST supply front and rear brakes on the ZR1 this equates to 800 discs per month from this contract alone with five other smaller contracts also now in series production. No doubt GM would of stockpiled as many discs as they could knowing Surface transforms manufacturing problems when GMs own production was delayed and severely affected by supply chain issues so I wouldn’t expect revenue for ST to mirror the ZR1 run rate, however the number of cars being produced per month currently is more than the first seven months of the year in total. Hopefully this bodes well for H2 production rates and revenue.

data.author: Al180
data.content: Welcome to LSE Inatthedeepend. I'm sure ST has a superior product to Brembo, they have better heat dispersion allowing them to run hotter and perform more consistently from cold than Brembo.  Particularly important to the OEMs  is they can get the required performance using a smaller disc. Although both companies produce ceramic brakes, Brembo use small fragments of carbon that are eventually turned into Silicon Carbide and ST start with a woven carbon matrix, Kevin Johnson compared the difference between the two  to  Chipboard and Plywood. There are other companies producing ceramic brakes for the racing market but they are a long way from entering the global safety critical supply chain,  ST and Brembo look like being the only option open to OEMs for some time to come.

So they have the best product in the world potentially...

data.author: Fevertreeman
data.content: 2012: full year revenues of c£2.4m (lower than forecast) 2022: full-year revenues of £5.1m (lower than revised forecasts)  .. 2023 : full year revenues of £7.3m below original/revised forecasts  (Jan 23..."the Company is not changing its guidance for 2023 and will be profitable" ; Apr 23 "Our overall profitability during FY 2023 is expected to be below market expectations." ); Nov '23 " As a result, the Company is reducing its sales guidance for the year to December 2023 to £8.6m" 2024: full-year revenues of £8.2m (lower than revised forecast)....  Jan '24 "The Company is maintaining its revenue guidance for 2024 at £23m" ; April '24 "projected FY 2024 range of £17.5m to £22m" ; Sept '24 " revenues ....now expected to be circa £11m .....significantly lower than current market expectations of £17.5m".

data.author: Fevertreeman
data.content: Inevitable that in the absence of news this drifts back - remember that we've had massive dilution here, and Kevin Johnson has serially f***** up so the real jury ( i.e. investors who have spent time understanding the product, the processes, the market , the customer base, and the barriers to entry)  remain highly sceptical of management's ability not to f*** this up again.  Johnson's history around forecasting, operational enhancements and scaling is dreadful. Given that furnace capacity is critical to the disc manufacturing process and therefore revenue, cashflow, & output, until we know for sure that Johnson hasnt yet again screwed it up, we're not likely to see any sustained recovery here. Although they've already telegraphed Q3 yield will be impacted by the installation, investors will be unlikely to pull the trigger until (10 we can see Q4 yields are steady and consistent c80pc (2) new CFO doing his thing and we're not about to have another liquidity issue.....we 're by no means out of the woods.....Cleminson has been superb in bringing us baxck from near death.....we're out of intensive care but still in the high dependency ward...my hope is that we can gradually move back to general ward, and then be discharged during 2026.

data.author: Al180
data.content: I’ve been looking into some numbers for the ZR1 relating to the current OEM10 contract. Initial production after a delay began in late April. By the end of July, only 180 units had been produced. Since then “Bloggers” that track production say it’s been growing quickly estimating 200 units per month run rate at the start of October. A search indicates ZR1 Bloggers use many different pieces of available information and are usually accurate. As ST supply front and rear brakes on the ZR1 this equates to 800 discs per month from this contract alone with five other smaller contracts also now in series production. No doubt GM would of stockpiled as many discs as they could knowing Surface transforms manufacturing problems when GMs own production was delayed and severely affected by supply chain issues so I wouldn’t expect revenue for ST to mirror the ZR1 run rate, however the number of cars being produced per month currently is more than the first seven months of the year in total. Hopefully this bodes well for H2 production rates and revenue.

data.author: Al180
data.content: Welcome to LSE Inatthedeepend. I'm sure ST has a superior product to Brembo, they have better heat dispersion allowing them to run hotter and perform more consistently from cold than Brembo.  Particularly important to the OEMs  is they can get the required performance using a smaller disc. Although both companies produce ceramic brakes, Brembo use small fragments of carbon that are eventually turned into Silicon Carbide and ST start with a woven carbon matrix, Kevin Johnson compared the difference between the two  to  Chipboard and Plywood. There are other companies producing ceramic brakes for the racing market but they are a long way from entering the global safety critical supply chain,  ST and Brembo look like being the only option open to OEMs for some time to come.

data.author: LatentValue
data.content: The lower productivity in H2 meant that rather than repay £3m of customer prepayments/advances in H2 as previously planned, they actually grew by over £0.4m.  Whilst this gap is disappointing it's now even clearer to me that GM/other OEMs should keep funding this project in the short/medium term until critical mass is achieved.  The working assumption between the company and funding OEMs must be that until this inflection point is reached, when a placing at a much higher market cap is more achievable and the prepayments can be settled from the raise, an early placing is not an option. Interesting also that at £27m sales they are suggesting breakeven EBITDA in FY26.  According to my financial model, £27m sales would result in positive EBITDA of £3m-£4m based on 77% yield.  It would therefore appear that they therefore are factoring in a big negative yield impact from the commissioning of the new furnace.  As per earlier comment: the OEMs would prepay this loss during H1. I would also hope IC has demanded great caution in the FY26 guidance, given the CEOs propensity to disappoint shareholders with over-optimistic guidance, today being a further example!

data.author: Al180
data.content: As long as the new CVI furnace becomes fully operational this year ST will be generating decent amounts of cash in 2026.  H2 2025 all going well will have been EBITDA  neutral  with £1m of cash at 2025 YE. This looks like the point where money could have got tight and the OEMs may have possibly made up a small shortfall but going forward capacity will double with the second CVI furnace. Demand is not an issue; the OEMs have wanted more discs than ST have been able to produce for a long time and  more of the £390m contracted pipeline kicks in this year. Unless yield or cash is well off the mark in the update progress with the new furnace is the most crucial thing,  apart from doubling capacity the second unit removes the last potential single point of failure in the production line

data.author: Al180
data.content: I’ve been looking into some numbers for the ZR1 relating to the current OEM10 contract. Initial production after a delay began in late April. By the end of July, only 180 units had been produced. Since then “Bloggers” that track production say it’s been growing quickly estimating 200 units per month run rate at the start of October. A search indicates ZR1 Bloggers use many different pieces of available information and are usually accurate. As ST supply front and rear brakes on the ZR1 this equates to 800 discs per month from this contract alone with five other smaller contracts also now in series production. No doubt GM would of stockpiled as many discs as they could knowing Surface transforms manufacturing problems when GMs own production was delayed and severely affected by supply chain issues so I wouldn’t expect revenue for ST to mirror the ZR1 run rate, however the number of cars being produced per month currently is more than the first seven months of the year in total. Hopefully this bodes well for H2 production rates and revenue.

data.author: Al180
data.content: Welcome to LSE Inatthedeepend. I'm sure ST has a superior product to Brembo, they have better heat dispersion allowing them to run hotter and perform more consistently from cold than Brembo.  Particularly important to the OEMs  is they can get the required performance using a smaller disc. Although both companies produce ceramic brakes, Brembo use small fragments of carbon that are eventually turned into Silicon Carbide and ST start with a woven carbon matrix, Kevin Johnson compared the difference between the two  to  Chipboard and Plywood. There are other companies producing ceramic brakes for the racing market but they are a long way from entering the global safety critical supply chain,  ST and Brembo look like being the only option open to OEMs for some time to come.

data.author: LatentValue
data.content: The lower productivity in H2 meant that rather than repay £3m of customer prepayments/advances in H2 as previously planned, they actually grew by over £0.4m.  Whilst this gap is disappointing it's now even clearer to me that GM/other OEMs should keep funding this project in the short/medium term until critical mass is achieved.  The working assumption between the company and funding OEMs must be that until this inflection point is reached, when a placing at a much higher market cap is more achievable and the prepayments can be settled from the raise, an early placing is not an option. Interesting also that at £27m sales they are suggesting breakeven EBITDA in FY26.  According to my financial model, £27m sales would result in positive EBITDA of £3m-£4m based on 77% yield.  It would therefore appear that they therefore are factoring in a big negative yield impact from the commissioning of the new furnace.  As per earlier comment: the OEMs would prepay this loss during H1. I would also hope IC has demanded great caution in the FY26 guidance, given the CEOs propensity to disappoint shareholders with over-optimistic guidance, today being a further example!

data.author: Al180
data.content: As long as the new CVI furnace becomes fully operational this year ST will be generating decent amounts of cash in 2026.  H2 2025 all going well will have been EBITDA  neutral  with £1m of cash at 2025 YE. This looks like the point where money could have got tight and the OEMs may have possibly made up a small shortfall but going forward capacity will double with the second CVI furnace. Demand is not an issue; the OEMs have wanted more discs than ST have been able to produce for a long time and  more of the £390m contracted pipeline kicks in this year. Unless yield or cash is well off the mark in the update progress with the new furnace is the most crucial thing,  apart from doubling capacity the second unit removes the last potential single point of failure in the production line

Just not sure why they didn't pull the trigger when the sp was a bit higher.

data.author: LatentValue
data.content: The lower productivity in H2 meant that rather than repay £3m of customer prepayments/advances in H2 as previously planned, they actually grew by over £0.4m.  Whilst this gap is disappointing it's now even clearer to me that GM/other OEMs should keep funding this project in the short/medium term until critical mass is achieved.  The working assumption between the company and funding OEMs must be that until this inflection point is reached, when a placing at a much higher market cap is more achievable and the prepayments can be settled from the raise, an early placing is not an option. Interesting also that at £27m sales they are suggesting breakeven EBITDA in FY26.  According to my financial model, £27m sales would result in positive EBITDA of £3m-£4m based on 77% yield.  It would therefore appear that they therefore are factoring in a big negative yield impact from the commissioning of the new furnace.  As per earlier comment: the OEMs would prepay this loss during H1. I would also hope IC has demanded great caution in the FY26 guidance, given the CEOs propensity to disappoint shareholders with over-optimistic guidance, today being a further example!

data.author: Al180
data.content: I would certainly think their  costs are significant especially with the UK having the most expensive industrial energy  in the world. There are also three different furnace processes in the production line some of which are very long. Starting with carbonisation then Chemical vapour infiltration (CVI) and finishing off with melt infiltration.

data.content: I contcted ST about the use of induction heating, which is far more controlled than a furnace, but they have just blanked every email I have ever sent.
data.thread_title: RE: Placing at 1.5p (unlikely) but not end of the world!

data.author: Al180
data.content: As long as the new CVI furnace becomes fully operational this year ST will be generating decent amounts of cash in 2026.  H2 2025 all going well will have been EBITDA  neutral  with £1m of cash at 2025 YE. This looks like the point where money could have got tight and the OEMs may have possibly made up a small shortfall but going forward capacity will double with the second CVI furnace. Demand is not an issue; the OEMs have wanted more discs than ST have been able to produce for a long time and  more of the £390m contracted pipeline kicks in this year. Unless yield or cash is well off the mark in the update progress with the new furnace is the most crucial thing,  apart from doubling capacity the second unit removes the last potential single point of failure in the production line
